JavaScript - Data Structures & Operators

Optional Chaining â€” ?. / ??

Without optional chaining a lengthy if statement is required to check for the presence of the property in openingHours:

if (restaurant.openingHours && restaurant.openingHours.mon)
              console.log(restaurant.openingHours.mon.open)

With optional chaining, the presence of the property is checked inline:

console.log(restaurant.openingHours.?fri?.open)
              
// example:
              const days = ['mon', 'tue', 'wed', 'thu', 'fri', 'sat', 'sun'];
              for (const day of days) {
                  const open = restaurant.openingHours[day]?.open ?? 'Closed';
                  // If restaurant.openingHours[day] exists, see if open. If not, display: 'Closed'
              }

Optional chaining with methods

console.log(restaurant.order?.(0, 1) ?? 'Method does not exist');

The above checks for a restaurant.order method. If with ?? it's falsey, it displays a message.

Optional chaining with arrays

const users = [
                  { name : 'Fred', email: 'Fred@mail.com' }
              ];
              
              console.log(users[0]?.name ?? 'User array empty');

Property Names & Values â€” .keys() / .values() / .entries()

Consider an object for opening hours:

const openingHours = {
                thu: {
                  open: 12,
                  close: 22,
                },
                fri: {
                  open: 11,
                  close: 23,
                },
                sat: {
                  open: 0, // Open 24 hours
                  close: 24,
                },
              };

Property names â€” Object.keys(-object-)

const properties = Object.keys(openingHours);
              console.log(properties) //=> Returns an array with all the keys in `openingHours`.

Property values â€” Object.values(-object-) 

const values = Object.values(openingHours);

Entire Object â€” Object.entries(openingHours)

const entries = Object.entries(openingHours);

[key, value]

for (const [day, { open, close }] of entries) {
                  console.log(`On ${day} we open at ${open} and close at ${close});
              }

The above iterates over array entries and for every day accesses the open and close property.

Sets â€” new Set()

Sets are arrays of which the content cannot appear more than once.

Consider:

const ordersSet = new Set(['Pasta', 'Pizza', 'Pizza', 'Risotto', 'Pasta', 'Pizza']);

Set modifiers

  • .size returns the size of the array
  • .has() checks for a certain item, like .includes
  • .add() Adds an item
  • .delete() Deletes an item
// Example: 
              const staff = ['Waiter', 'Chef', 'Waiter', 'Manager', 'Chef', 'Waiter'];
              
              // Array to Set and then to array with spread operator:
              const staffUnique = [...new Set(staff)];

Maps â€” new Map()

Maps can be more useful than Sets and can store key/value pairs in sets. Maps can contain any type of keys.

const rest = new Map();
              
              // Add item -> .set(key, value);
              rest.set('name', 'Classico Italiano');
              rest.set(1, 'Firenze, Italy');
              rest.set(2, 'Lisbon', 'Portugal');
              console.log(rest.set('Style', 'Italian'));

Chaining .set()

rest
                  .set('categories', ['Italian', 'Pizzaria'])
                  .set('open', 11)
                  .set('close', 23)
                  .set(true, 'We are open! ðŸ˜ƒ')
                  .set(false, 'We are closed ðŸ˜Ÿ');
              
                  // Is the restaurant open now?
                  console.log(rest.get(time > rest.get('open') && time < rest.get('close'))); //==> returns `rest.true` or `rest.false`

Check and delete objects

// Check for objects
              rest.has('categories') //=> TRUE
              
              // Delete an object:
              rest.delete('categories');
              
              // Clear complete object:
              rest.clear();

Maps Iteration

Consider:

const question = new Map([
                ['question', 'What is the best programming language?'],
                [1, 'C'],
                [2, 'Java'],
                [3, 'JavaScript'],
                ['correctAns', 3],
                [true, "That\'s correct!"],
                [false, "Try again!"]
              ]);

Iteration with the for loop:

console.log(question.get('question'));
              for (const [key, value] of question) {
                if (typeof key === 'number') console.log(`Answer ${key}: ${value}`)
              }

Spread operator to convert map to array

console.log([...question]) //=> Returns an array of question

Working with Strings

Strings are very flexible and can be modified the same way that arrays can:

const airline = 'TAP Air Portugal';
              const plane = 'A320';
              
              console.log(
                plane[0],
                plane[1],
                plane[2]
              );
              
              console.log('B737'[0]);
              console.log(airline.length);
              console.log('B747'.length);

String methods

  • .indexOf('a')
  • .lastIndexOf('z')
  • .slice(start, end)
  • .trim()
  • .toLowerCase()
  • .toUpperCase()
  • .replace('[set]', '[to]')
//String Methods
              console.log(`position of the first 'r' is ${airline.indexOf('r')}`);
              console.log(`position of the last 'r' is ${airline.lastIndexOf('r')}`);
              console.log(`position of 'Portugal' is ${airline.indexOf('Portugal')}`);
              
              //Slicing strings
              console.log(airline.slice(4)) //Always returns a NEW STRING
              console.log(airline.slice(4, 7));
              
              //Soft code slicing
              console.log(airline.slice(0, airline.indexOf(' '))) //Slices first word
              console.log(airline.slice(airline.lastIndexOf(' ') + 1)) //Slices last word
              
              console.log(airline.slice(-2)); //Slices last 2 letters
              console.log(airline.slice(1, -1)); //Slices first letter and last letter

Fix name capitalization

//Fix capitalization in name
              const passenger = 'fReDerik';
              const passengerLower = passenger.toLowerCase();
              const passengerCorrect = passengerLower[0].toUpperCase() + passengerLower.slice(1);
              console.log(passengerCorrect);

Replacing (parts of) strings â€” .replace('[set]', '[to]')

const priceGB = '244,93â‚¤';
              const priceUS = priceGB.replace('â‚¤', '$').replace(',', '.');

Using RegEx allows all instances of a string to be replaced:

const announcement = 'All passengers come to boarding door 32, boarding door 32'
              console.log(announcement.replaceAll('boarding door', 'gate'));
              
              console.log(announcement.replace(/boarding door/g, 'gate').replace(/32/g, 53));

String Split & Join â€” .split(' ') / .join(' ')

console.log('a+very+nice+string'.split('+'));
              console.log('Frederik DeVilder'.split(' '));
              
              const [firstName, lastName] = 'Frederik DeVilder'.split(' ');
              console.log(firstName);

Padding a string â€” .padStart(1, ' ') / .padEnd(1, ' ')

const message = 'Go to gate 24!';
              message.padStart(22, '->')
              'now'.padEnd(23, '->')
              
              const maskCreditCard = (number) => {
                const str = number + ''; //Converts the number to a string
                const last = str.slice(-4);
                return last.padStart(str.length, "*");
              }
              maskCreditCard(4330583442)
              maskCreditCard('8749913123')

Repeat a string with a method â€” .repeat(2) 

const message2 = 'Bad weather... All Departures Delayed ';
              
              console.log(message2.repeat(4))
              
              const planesInLine = (n) => {
                console.log(`There are ${n} planes in line ${'âœˆ'.repeat(n)}`)
              }
              
              planesInLine(3);
              planesInLine(6);
              planesInLine(9);
